conclusion: Understanding conditions for total internal reflection and angle relations.
Light a and b are perpendicular to the hypotenuse and enter the glass from the air.
Angle of incidence is between incident ray and normal to surface.
Critical angle for TIR is when refracted ray is at 90 degrees to boundary.
Critical angle formula: θc = sin⁻¹(1/n), where n is refractive index.
Refractive index of glass is na for light a and nb for light b.
Refractive index relates to speed of light in medium and vacuum.
Refractive indices differ for different colors due to dispersion.
Light a and b are incident at the same angle from glass to air.
As angle of incidence increases, angle of refraction increases.
Light with higher refractive index has smaller critical angle, undergoes TIR at lower incidence angle.
Critical angle for light a: θc,a = sin⁻¹(1/na).
Critical angle for light b: θc,b = sin⁻¹(1/nb).
Since nb > na, θc,b < θc,a, light b undergoes TIR first.
Light b will first reach critical angle and undergo TIR before light a.
Statement 'light b will first undergo total internal reflection' is correct.
